P. ha decidido apoyar desde hace 4 años directamente a su esposo en el taller mecánico, ella supervisa y cuida el taller cuando el Sr. Palacios va a comprar refacciones o a atender a algún cliente fuera del taller; él tiene mas de 20 años en este oficio. “La esperanza es lo ultimo que se pierde, no vamos a darnos por vencidos; teníamos parte de la cubierta del taller, pero el viento la derribo; tenemos muchos clientes ya que mi marido es muy buen mecánico solo que por la falta de recursos no hemos podido crecer nos hace falta equipo y herramienta; solicitamos $1,500 dlls. Para salir adelante.”

loans.use: Para adquirir equipo y herramienta

loans.name: Rusni

texts.en:
Rusni, 39 years old, is a mother of 5 children. She has already opened her small kiosk before she joined as one of MBK member. Her lack of capital to support and to expand her small kiosk was her main reason to join MBK. She is hoping to get a chance to get more capital from MBK which has a light repayment plan.

With a working capital of $50 she can sell more items in her small kiosk such as cigarette, flour, shampoo and also vegetables.

Rusni's husband, Ahab, is a farmer. Therefore some part of the loan will be given to her husband to purchase fertilizer and seeds.

Translated from Indonesian by Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To support the capital for her kiosk.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en: Munira J. and her husband work at the secondary school. She is a teacher of the native language and a teacher of the knitting group. They have three girls. Munira dreams of two of her daughters becoming doctors and the other one a teacher. Munira and her husband used their first loan to purchase a bull. Now they plan to purchase another two bulls. It will take them approximately $1500 USD. They have their savings and hope to receive the requested loan.

loans.use: purchase 2 bulls

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John B. is a Ugandan from the Muyankole tribe. He is a client of Life in Africa , through which he received his first Kiva loan. He resigned from his previous job to work with Life in Africa, where he is employed as a gardener. John is very dedicated to his work.

His first loan request was for $480 to finish building his house, which he successfully completed. He made regular payments for the first four months but faced some difficulties paying in the last two months because his wife, who was expecting, fell ill and later delivered. Happily, he eventually paid off his loan in full.

John is now requesting a loan to build a kitchen so as to separate the living room in his house from the kitchen. As the project will cost $300 and John has just $150 in savings, he is requesting a loan for the other $150 from Kiva.

Apart from his gardening work at Life in Africa, John has a shop that will help him repay his loan. Once given this loan he will be able to repay in three months.

Below is his budget: (The individual items are denoted in Ugandan shillings and the total has been converted to US$)

8 iron sheets of 32 gauge @ 12,000/= …………….96,000

1000 bricks @ 70…………………………………...70,000

5, bags of cement @ 20,000……………………….100,000/=

8 roofing timbers @ 5500…………………………..44,000/=

2 trips of sand @ 60,000…………………………..120,000/=

4kgs of nails @ 2500………………………………10,000/=

Labor @ 60,000……………………………………..60,000/=

Total………………………………………………..500,000/= ($300 : $150 from John's savings and $150 from a Kiva loan)

loans.use: Buying building materials

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa is an 18 year old artisan. She is married and has one son. She works as an embroider of blouses, wallets and pillows. She sells her work in San Cristobal and in other communities that are closer to where she lives. She is part of the group Espina 7, togehter with doña Andrea Díaz Gómez (artisan) ,doña Maria Hernández Hernández 1st (artisan) y doña María Hernández Hernández 2nd (artisan) . They will invest this loan into purchasing threads from various colors for their artisan work.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

TERESA, es artesana tiene 18 años, es casada y tiene un hijo, ella se dedica al bordado de blusas, monederos y cojines los cuales vende en la ciudad de San Cristóbal o en las comunidades mas cercanas a su hogar. Pertenece al grupo Espina 7 junto con doña Andrea Díaz Gómez (artesana) ,doña Maria Hernández Hernández 1era (artesana) y doña María Hernández Hernández 2da (artesana) Con sus préstamos invertirán en hilos De colores variados para sus artesanías

loans.use: purchase threads for artisan work

loans.name: Rehimatu

texts.en: Mrs. Rehimatu U. is a 38-year-old fashion designer who lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is married and has three children. She has seven years of experience in business and has been a member of LAPO for four years. She is in need of $400 to enable her buy more clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Muinat

texts.en: Muinat is 39 years old, married and has 4 children; she comes from Mushin in Lagos State. She sells weavon and attachments and is also a stylist. She requests the loan to buy more weavon and attachments. She has been in business since 1995.

loans.use: To buy weavon and attachment

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
Modesta is a humble mother whose life has always been connected to ranching and farming. This experience and the effort that she puts into her family every day is reflected in her household. She and her husband have lovingly created a stable home. Every day the couple leaves home very early to take care of their cows and bulls in order to provide for their five dear children who are all students at the community's modest education center. Their main activity during the sowing and harvest season is livestock. They purchase animals so that after a certain period of time they can sell them at the Acostambo fair. This hard-working family's wish is to receive a loan so that they can purchase more feed for their beloved animals.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Modesta, es una humilde madre de familia, su vida siempre ha estado vinculada a las actividades agrícolas, gracias a este hecho obtuvo mucha experiencia la cual se ve reflejada ahora en su hogar debido al esfuerzo que le dedica día a día a esta labor en beneficio de su familia.Ella y su esposo han forjado con mucho amor un hogar sólido y a diario desde muy temprano abandonan su hogar en compañía de sus vaquitas y toros, en búsqueda del sustento diario de sus cinco queridos hijos que aún se encuentran estudiando en el modesto centro educativo de su comunidad. Su principal actividad en épocas de siembra y cosecha es la ganadería, compran animales para al cabo de un tiempo venderlos en la feria de Acostambo.El deseo de esta trabajadora familia es obtener un préstamo para adquirir mayor cantidad de alimento para sus queridos animalitos.

loans.use: To buy more cattle feed.

loans.name: Osenatou

texts.fr:
Married and the mother of two children, Mrs. Osénatou S. was born on November 3, 1967 in Porto-Novo (the political capital of Benin) in the district of Oueme. She is currently requesting her third loan. She has proven to be an exemplary borrower here at ALIDé, since she has been very punctual in reimbursing her previous loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mariée, mère de 02 enfants, Dame S. Osénatou est née le 03/11/1967 à Porto-Novo (Capitale politique du Bénin) dans le Département de l'OUEME. Elle en est à son troisième crédit. Exemplaire parmi les bénéficiaires de crédit à ALIDé, elle a toujours été régulière et ponctuelle dans les remboursements des crédits antérieurs.

loans.use:
Purchasing 7 bolts of African print cloth in the "Hitarget" pattern and 3 of "Wax Hollandais" pattern

Achat de 07 pièces de pagne « HITARGET » et 03 pièces de pagne « WAX HOLLANDAIS »

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is 25 years old and married with one child.  Salamatu continued running her small business after getting married. Her husband is unemployed and she sells palm oil, wheat flour and other food items in the market in Markeni town of Sierra Leone. She said it was because of the loan capital from SMT that she was able to increase her stock and profit.  Salamatu is one of SMT’s best clients who meets her loan obligations on time.  She is now requesting more loans to expand her business.

loans.use: Salamatu is a young entrepreneur with a lot of potential.  She has a keen eye for business and is excited to take the next steps in expanding and diversifying her business.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda R. D. P. runs a family store selling spare motorcycle parts in the city of Pucallpa, in the Ucayali region of Peru. She opened the store six years ago with her husband. They have a great location on a main road connecting Pucallpa with the town of Yurmicucha.

Belinda is 51 years old with two children and is happily married. Before she opened the store, Belinda had a business renting motorcycles and scooters. She left the business because she was the victim of too many robberies and assaults. The change has been good, and she can now live more calmly.

A member of the community bank Las Abejitas, Belinda is requesting a loan of $1,100 to repay over four months. She will use the loan to restock the products she sells that are in low supply and or are popular.

loans.use: To restock products for her motorcycle parts store

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma, age 36, is married and cares for three children, her 15 year old, and two other children, ages 9 and 21. She runs a small general store, a business she started in 2005. She works from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily, and makes a monthly profit of about $90.

Rahma hopes for a loan to purchase more inventory for her shop. She is a member of the Tushikamane loan group whose members guarentee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her general store

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Chey D., a fish seller earning around $3 per day, is married and lives with five children in Sneng Krabey Village, Kampong Thom Province. Her husband, Mr. Noun Vanna, is a fisherman who makes around $4 per day. Their children are young and attend school, so D. and her husband have a large responsibility supporting the family and paying the children’s school fees. In order to expand their businesses, D. seeks a loan to purchase more fish stocks as well as a boat for her husband’s fishing operation.

loans.use: To purchase more fish stocks and a boat  for her husband's fishing business.

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Believe in God is the name of this group and its members are Ramatu C. and Ramatu K.. The former sells local produce, such as palm kernels and rice. The latter sells firewood. Firewood is used extensively for cooking in almost every household in Sierra Leone.

This group is seeking a loan of Le 2,000,000.00 to expand their businesses. These women have been with SMT for over a year now and have always repaid their loans successfully. Ramatu C. was born in Magburaka about 30 miles from Makeni City. She stays with her husdand and four children in Makeni. She has been in the local produce business for over ten years now.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm-oil, palm kernels, and firewood.

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.en:
T. Tursunoy is 48 years old. She is separated from her husband and raising her son alone. She began her business to keep herself busy and active when she found herself sad and depressed due to her separation, as well as to have an independent income. Having only one son, she is doing her best to make him well-educated and happy.

Tursunoy is a market vendor. She is selling clothes for kids. As a rule, she travels to the neighboring city to purchase the goods with the help of her son. In general, her business is stable and has strong potential for further development. However, Tursunoy stresses that after loans provided by the International Micro-Loan Fund IMON, she managed to accelerate the development of her business considerably. For instance with one of the loans, Tursunoy rented one more trading place in the market.

Today she is planning to increase her working capital in order to expand her business. For this purpose she requests 800 USD for the term of 12 months. Tursunoy promises to mange the current loan with accuracy as she did all the previous ones and thanks everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: Increase working capital to develop her business.

loans.name: Zoumana

texts.fr:
Monsieur Kanté Zoumana âgé de 48 ans, marié et  père de 7 enfants. Il vit dans une famille polygame avec ses deux épouses, ses enfants et ses parents dans le quartier Bamannankin de Ouelessebougou (une des sous préfectures de la région de Koulikoro). Il exerce la boucherie depuis 12 ans. Cette activité est une activité familiale et était exercé par son père auprès duquel il la apprit. Il exerce cette activité au marché de Ouelessebougou situé au bord de la route reliant le Mali à La république de Cote d’ivoire.
Dans son souci d’élargir son activité et de faire face à une demande de plus en plus croissante, monsieur Kanté décida de s’adresser à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel. Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter deux bœufs en raison de 125.000 FCFA  l’unité. Les bœufs sont abattus et vendu au détail à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes et de restaurateurs. L’abattage est effectué chaque deux jours. Monsieur Zoumana Kanté mène une activité très rentable et compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 135.000 FCFA. Une grande partie de ce bénéfice est utilisée pour faire face aux dépenses de la famille élargie (père, mère, sœurs, frères, femmes et enfants).
A la longue il compte construire une boucherie moderne lui permettant de respecter les normes sanitaires.
texts.en:
Mr. Zoumana Kanté is 48 years old, married and the father of 7 children. He lives in a polygamous family with two spouses, his children and his relatives in the Bamannankin district of Ouelessebougou (one of the subprefectures of the Koulikoro region). He has worked as a butcher for 12 years. This is a family profession and he learned it from his father who was also a butcher. He runs this business at the Ouelessebougou market located along the road connecting Mali and the Republic of the Ivory Coast. Concerned about expanding his business and faced with an ever-growing demand, Mr. Kanté decided to go to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is his first individual loan. It will be used to buy two steers at a cost of 125,000F CFA each. The steers are slaughtered and sold as retail to a clientele made up primarily of women and restaurant owners. The slaughtering takes place every two days. Mr. Zoumana Kanté runs a very profitable business and hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 135,000F CFA. A large part of this revenue is used to deal with the expenses of his large family (father, mother, sisters, brothers, wives and children). Eventually he plans to build a modern butchery allowing him to respect health standards.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of steers for butchering

loans.name: Yudith Roxana

texts.es:
Yudith tiene 23 años de edad, estudió cuarto de secundaria, es conviviente y madre de un niño de 04 años de edad. Vive en el Jr. Ejército s/n (frente al mercado), distrito de Mazocruz, provincia El Collao, Puno.

Desde el año 2005 integra el Banco Comunal “Generación 2000” en Mazocruz. Por motivos familiares tuvo que dejar el Banco Comunal, reingresando nuevamente hace dos ciclos. Con el crédito que le otorgaron de S/.500 Nuevos Soles pudo comprar 03 cabezas de alpaca. 

Yudith empezó a dedicarse al negocio desde que tuvo su pareja, a los 22 años de edad, con la venta de carne y fibra de alpaca, llama y también carne y lana de ovino que entrega a los mayoristas de la ciudad de Tacna. De vez en cuando prepara comida para vender en la feria sabatina de Mazocruz.

Con este crédito de S/.800 Nuevos Soles, el cual será cancelado en 04 cuotas, comprará 05 cabezas de alpaca que será entregado en carne a los mayoristas.

Su meta es comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ilave, apoyar a su hijo hasta que sea profesional. También piensa llevar productos de abarrotes a las diferentes ferias para generar más ganancias.
texts.en:
Yudith is 23 years old and completed a fourth of primary school. She is married and mother of a four year old son. She lives in Jr. Ejército (in front of the market), district of Mazocurz, province of El Collao, Puno. In 2005, she joined the community bank "Generación 2000" in Mazocruz. For family reasons, she had to leave the community bank, and rejoin after two cycles. With the credit of 500 Soles that they granted her, she was able to buy three heads of alpaca. Yudith began to dedicate herself to this business since she has been with her husband, at the age of 22, with the sale of meat and fiber from alpacas and llamas, and also meat and wool from sheep, which she sells to the wholesalers of the city of Tacna. Sometimes she prepares food to sell at the Saturday market in Mazocruz. With this loan of 800 Soles, which she will repay in four months, she will buy five heads of alpaca that she will sell as meat to wholesalers. Her goal is to buy a home in the city of Ilave and support her son until he becomes a professional. She also plans to deliver grocery products to the various markets to generate more earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: five head of alpaca

loans.name: Safinia

texts.en:
Safinia, 30 years old and divorced with two children, has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for seven years. She is currently able to earn approximately $20 each month and is now seeking her first loan so that she can buy more ingredients to increase her cooking capacity.

.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for cooking and selling food.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is 48 years old and the married mother of four children. Her children are currently in school. Beatrice sells frozen foods in the local market to support her family.  She says demand for fish is high but she does not have the capital requirement to meet such demands. She wants to use the loan to purchase more cartons of frozen foods to enable her to raise enough income to support her children's education. She is a member of the borrowing group called Angels. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, mutton, etc.

loans.name: Lila Margarita

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Lila E., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva, estoy casada y soy madre, tengo mi pequeño negocio el cual me genera ingresos para ayudarle a mi esposo con los gastos de nuestro hogar, para esta epoca de navidad necesito un credito para poder comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener mas variedad de productos y tambien mejorar las ganancias, las cuales las necesito para darles una mejor calidad de vida a mi familia.
texts.en:
Hello my name is Lila E., and I sell new clothes. I am married, and I am a mother. I have my small business which generates income to help my husband with our living expenses. This time around Christmas, I am asking for a loan to purchase more merchandise and consequently offer a greater variety of products to improve earnings. This is what I need to give my family a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en: Margaret W. is the proud owner of a retail shop in Kisimba. She is 38 years old and married with 4 children. In her retail shop, Margaret has been able to retain her customers and attract more by stocking her shop with products that appeal to everyone. She sells sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, maize flour and many other things that are a necessity in a village. Margaret needs a loan to be able to buy more products so as to expand her business and make more profit.

loans.use: More shop products for shop expansion.

loans.name: José Santos

texts.es: José Santos B. F., reside en Cojutepeque, departamento de Cuscatlán, en El Salvador, vive con su esposa, su pequeña hija de 10 meses de edad y su bisabuela de 68 años de edad, la cuál trabaja en una pequeña tienda. José Santos, es un hombre trabajador que tiene como visión brindarle un mejor estilo de vida a su familia y poder ofrecerle un mejor futuro a su pequeña hija. Por ello desea obtener un nuevo préstamo por parte de integral, ya que con anterioridad había obtenido otros préstamos los cuales logro pagar al día. Dicha solicitud la realiza con la esperanza de poder comprar productos para el cabello y las uñas y poder brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes y lograr sacar adelante su negocio y así percibir mejores ganancias que contribuyan a suplir las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
José Santos B. F. lives in Cojutepeque, in the Cuscatlán province of El Salvador. José Santos lives with his wife and their young daughter, who is only 10 months old. They also live with José Santos' great grandmother, who is 68 years old and works in a small store. José Santos is a hard-working man who has a vision of providing a better lifestyle for his family. He'd also like to offer a better future for his young daughter. Because of this, José Santos would like to take out a new loan as part of a comprehensive lending plan. José Santos has loaned in the past and has always made payments on time. He asks for this loan with the hope that he can buy hair and nail products in order to provide better service to his clients. In this way his business will get ahead and he'll earn more money to satisfy his family's needs.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy new hair and nail products

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Katoura

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier d’agoè demakpoè, elle a pour activité principale la vente de bijoux, pagnes, foulards et assiettes, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005 et elle le fait de façon ambulante, elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de lomé et chez des fournisseurs venus du benin, elle vend à crédit à certaines bonne dame et récupère son argent après, son commerce marche bien et  elle voudrait agrandir son stock de marchandises par l’achat de 20 pièces de pagnes et 15 ensembles de bijoux. Elle est mariée et a un enfant.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Agoè Demakpoè district. Her work involves selling jewelry, pagnes cloth, scarves, and plates. She has been in this business since 2005 and goes door-to-door as she works. She supplies herself at the grand marketplace of Lomé and through suppliers from Benin. She sells on credit to certain nice ladies and collects her money afterwards. Her commerce is doing well, and she would like to increase her inventory of merchandise by buying 20 lengths of pagnes and 15 sets of jewelry. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and jewelry for resale

loans.name: Cristina

texts.es: La señora Cristina M. elabora joyas que las lucen las personas  de pollera  en las fiestas folklóricas como ser la Fiesta del Gran Poder y la fiesta Universitaria, solamente tiene un operario quien trabaja todo el día mientras la señora visita las clientas, vive en una pequeña casita junto a su hija que esta en edad escolar la que también sabe del oficio ya que le ayuda a la mama en su tiempo libre, ya que es el único ingreso con el que cubre los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Cristina M. makes jewelry that people in folk festivals such as "la Fiesta del Gran Poder" (The Festival of Great Power, a festival in La Paz, Bolivia) and university festivals wear on their skirts. The business has only has one operator who works the whole day while Cristina visits the customers. She lives in a small house with her school-age daughter. Her daughter is familiar with the operation since she helps her mother during her free time. It is their only source of income for their family expenditures.

Translated from Spanish by Annie Sheng, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of jewels and stones for jewelry-making

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Libertad  inicia su cuarto ciclo con 18 socias.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. cereales, panes, frutas, comidas, lencería, jugos D. frutas, tubérculos, abarrotes en general y ropa.

Como es el caso D. Edith que es conviviente, tiene 33 años y 3 hijos, Edith tiene un puesto en el mercado Carmen Alto en donD. venD. papa variada, actividad que realiza todos los días.

Por otro lado Herminia es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Herminia venD. comida D. manera ambulatoria en el mercado Magdalena, actividad que realiza todos los días por las mañanas.

Mientras que Eugenia es casada, tiene 35 años y 1 hijo, Eugenia se dedica a la venta D. mercerías, D. manera ambulatoria en el mercado Magdalena.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 450 soles,  600soles haciendo un total D. 10,250 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra D. arroz, fideo, golosinas, muebles, galoneras, trigo, maíz, frutas, ropa y papa. 

Los sueños D. las socias son mejorar sus negocios, tener un loca propio, construir su casa y surtir con mas productos sus negocios.
texts.en:
The "Libertad" Communal Bank begins its fourth cycle with 18 members. The members have different business, such as the sale of cereals, breads, fruit, food, linen goods, fruit juice, tubers, general groceries and clothing. Edith has a live-in partner, is 33 years old and has 3 children. She has a stall at the Carmen Alto market where she sells various types of potatoes, an activity that she does every day. Herminia, who has a live-in partner, is 35 years old and has 2 children. She sells food from a vending cart in the Magdalena market, an activity that she does every day in the mornings. Eugenia is married, is 35 years old and has 1 son. She sells merchandise from a vending cart in the Magdalena market. The members need different loan amounts, such as 300, 450 and 600 soles, making a total of 10,250 soles in loans from the Communal Bank. Their loans will be invested in the purchase of rice, noodles, candies, furniture, gallon jugs, wheat, corn, fruit, clothing and potatoes. The dream of the members is to improve their businesses, to have their own sites, to build their own houses and to offer a greater assortment of products in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, noodles, candies, furniture, gallon jugs, wheat, corn, fruit, clothing and potatoes.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: Esperanza tiene 31 años, vive con su pareja Ladislao de 42, y sus hijos; ellos tienen un terreno propio, pero alquilan una casa que les sirve como taller para su negocio. Desde hace 10 años se ha venido dedicando a su taller de planchado y pintado de autos, decidieron incursionar en este negocio por las habilidades que tenían su esposo para el arreglo de autos, desde entonces han avanzado poco a poco con su negocio y hoy en día sus servicios son muy demandados, lo cual les llevó a contratar a dos jóvenes para que los ayuden. Por unidad y según el daño del vehículo, llegan a cobrar hasta 750 soles, lo cual es invertido en comprar planchas de metal y otros materiales para que el vehiculo quede en buenas condiciones. A Esperanza le gusta mucho su trabajo y siendo mujer no le ve impedimento para realizarlo, nos dice que prefiere más el trabajo duro en su taller que la labor de cocina en su hogar. Tanto ella como su esposo esperan seguir trabajando duro para salir adelante y mejorar su negocio. Con MFP, es su tercer préstamo y siempre ha sido muy puntual con todos los pagos de sus cuotas. El dinero que viene solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de material para arreglar vehículos; como planchas de metal, pintura, masilla, etc., y así poder brindar un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Esperanza, 31, lives with her partner, Ladislao, 42, and their children. They have their own place but they rent a house that they use as a workshop for the business. For 10 years, Esperanza has operated an auto body repair and paint shop. They decided to start the business because her husband is skilled at repairing and painting auto bodies. The business has grown little by little and their services are now in such demand that they have two employees to help them. They charge up to 750 soles per vehicle, depending on what damage was done, some of which they spend on buying the materials they need to return the vehicle to good condition. Esperanza very much enjoys the work and being a woman has never been an impediment to doing it. She tells us that she prefers the hard work of the shop to the drudgery of her kitchen at home. Her husband, as well as she herself, hope to continue working hard to get ahead and improve the business. This is Esperanza's third MFP loan and she's always been punctual about repaying past loans. She will use this loan to buy materials for repairing vehicles: metal panels, paint, mastic, etc. so that the business can provide a better service.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for auto body repair service.

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en: At 53, Felicitas L. helps her husband earn a living through her variety store. Her husband is an on-call carpenter in their village. With five children, Felicitas experienced financial problems since her business is small and her income is just enough for their food expenses. She is planning to expand her business with additional capital from an HSPFI micro-finance loan amounting to PHP 5,000.00. With this, she may be able to increase her income and cater to the rising demands in her local market.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her store

loans.name: Lukaya

texts.en:
Lukaya A. is forty years of age. She is a married mother of three children – one son and two daughters. She says they are in the senior high, junior high and primary schools. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana.

Lukaya is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice and stew. She prepares the food in her house and sells it on a table by a road side in her community. She buys bags of rice and other ingredients from shops in her town. She sells from morning to afternoon.

Lukaya has been in business for over eighteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. She desires to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchasing raw materials to process

loans.name: Exsilda's Group

texts.es:
La señora Exsilda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Ana”, Distrito de Moyobamba, Provincia Moyobamba, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 63 años y 10 hijos, todos ya independientes y cada uno con su familia.

Exsilda es una mujer luchadora, que a su edad le gusta trabajar y generar sus propios ingresos, decidió implementar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, que se encuentra ubicada en su misma casa, empezó poco a poco y ahora a mejorado bastante y sus productos están al alcance de sus clientes y amas de casas, donde encuentran lo que necesitan. En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y nos cuenta que le va muy bien.  

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, utensilios de aseo para el hogar y de higiene personal, paquetes de gaseosas de diferentes sabores y marcas para de esta manera satisfacer y brindar una mejor  atención a sus clientes. 

Exsilda, se siente una mujer muy satisfecha con lo que ha  logrado. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y a cumplir sus sueños y metas y otras  mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Ms. Exsilda is a member of Santa Ana Community Bank in the District of Moyobamba, Moyobamba Province, State of San Martin. She is 63 years old and has 10 children, all of whom are own their own and raise their own families. She lives with her common law husband. Ms. Exsilda is determined and strong-willed. At her age, she still wants to work and earn a living. She decided to start her own grocery business in her home. She started gradually and has improved it considerably. Her products are within reach of her customers and housewives, who are able to find what they need at her store. She currently owns the same business and reports that things are going well. With the S/ 1,000.00 loan she will buy rice and sugar by the sack, packaged noodles, a variety of brands of boxed milk and canned fish, cleaning supplies and personal hygiene items, as well as several flavors and brands of soft drinks that will allow her to better meet her customers' needs. Ms. Exsilda is very satisfied with her success. She would like to thank the Manuela Ramos Movement for the help provided to launch her business and fulfill her dreams and goals, and for the help they provide other enterprising women.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries with the goal of offering a greater variety

loans.name: Rosalina Elizabeth

texts.es: la joven Rosalina A., de 24 años de edad, es una mujer de iniciativa, soltera y vive con sus padres,  su negocio es la venta de cosméticos, ropa, y prendas, desde hace tres años, anteriormente trabajaba en una empresa como afanadora y con su liquidación inicio su negocio, con esta solicitud de crédito quiere invertir en la compra de joya, cosmético para a aumentar las ventas y poder obtener un mejor margen de ganancias, a si como captar clientes nuevos. Su meta es poder seguir estudiando en la universidad Mercadotecnia que por falta de capital hasta ahora no iniciado, pero lo lograra.
texts.en:
Rosalina A. is a 24 year old woman who is full of initiative. She is single and lives with her parents. For 3 years, she has been in the business of selling cosmetics, clothing and jewelry. She previously worked as a cleaning lady at an office, but when her employer went out of business, she applied for a loan so that she could buy jewelry to sell. Later, she started selling cosmetics to increase her sales and was able to achieve a better profit margin and attract new customers.

Her goal is to attend college and earn a degree in marketing. She doesn’t have the funds at the moment to enroll, but she eventually will.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase silver jewelry and cosmetics

loans.name: Inácio Feliciano

texts.pt:
Inácio Feliciano M., de 48 anos de idade, Natural de Lichinga, província de Niassa, casado e pai de 02 filhos menores de 05 e 03 anos de idade, não vive na casa própria, fez 3º ano de engenharia eletrônica (nível básico), parou de estudar por causa de problemas financeiros. Sustenta a sua família com ajuda da esposa que é estudante e vendedora.

Nasceu em Lichinga (3.200 km a norte de Maputo) onde os seus pais estiveram a viver e em missão de serviço, tendo voltado para Maputo pouco tempo depois do seu nascimento.

É Professor afecto na casa do Gaiato (Orfanato e escola de artes e oficio de Boane) há mais de 07 anos. Teve formação de curta duração, apenas participou de um seminário em 2000. O seu rendimento mensal é de 6000,00MT com o qual e com ajuda da esposa que é vendedora (faz pequenos negócios na sua residência e em regime ambulatório) sustenta a sua família e consegue poupar para puder construir a sua residência.

Conheceu a Hluvuku-Adsema através de amigos e este é o seu primeiro empréstimo, nunca teve empréstimo em nenhuma outra instituição.

Com o credito de 25.000,00MT pretende comprar blocos, areia, cimento, chapa de zinco, barrotes e outros materiais de construção. O seu maior desafio e concluir a sua casa e continuar a estudar.
Propõe-se a pagar o credito sem problemas para poder aceder a outros empréstimos para electrificar e mobiliar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Inácio Feliciano M. is 48 years old. He was born in Lichinga, province of Niassa. He’s married and has 2 young children, ages 5 and 3. He doesn’t own his house. He completed three years of Electronic Engineering (basic level), but he dropped school due to financial problems. He supports his family with the help of his wife, who’s a student and a sales woman. He was born in Lichinga (3,200 km north of Maputo) where his parents lived while completing a service mission returning to Maputo soon after he was born. He has been a Professor on Casa do Gaiato (orphanage and arts and crafts school in Boane) for more than 7 years. He had a short professional education; he only took a seminar in 2000. His monthly salary reaches 6000,00MT. With that money he helps his wife, who’s a sale woman (she does small businesses at home and door to door). This way they support their family and are able to save to finish building their home. He met Hluvuku-Adsema through some friends. This is his first loan and he never received any loans from any other association. With this 25,000.00MT loan he would like to purchase bricks, sand, cement, zinc plates, bars and other construction material. His biggest challenge is to finish building his home and to continue studying. He’s determined to repay this loan without a problem in order to be able to request for other loans to connect the electricity and buy furniture for his home.

Translated from Portuguese by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.en:
Apolinaria L. is from the village of Katipa. She is 58 years old. Apolinaria is married and has 9 adult-aged children. To make a living, Apolinaria sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Apolinaria has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Apolinaria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Apolinaria successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase raw ingredients. She is requesting her 9th loan from PMPC for 10000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional inventory and generate working capital.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Anllela

texts.es:
Anllela  es una socia colaboradora y entusiasta en su grupo, tiene 30 años de edad, es madre de un niño, ella se dedica a la venta  de gaseosas, chupetes y hielo, esto lo realiza en su misma casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo, él administra una discoteca. Ella es socia del Banco Comunal “Dulce Vida” desde hace hace dos años, su primer préstamo fue de 300 soles, monto que invirtió en la apertura de su actual negocio. 
Con este crédito de S/ 2,300 soles, piensa comprar un motokar para así tener otra fuente de ingreso en su hogar y poder lograr tener otro negocio en su casa. La  meta de Anllela es tener un local propio como una fuente de soda  y así ofrecer una variedad de refrescos, gaseosas, cremoladas  y  otras bebidas.
texts.en:
Anllela is a helpful and enthusiastic member in her group, is 30 years old, and is mother to a young child. She makes a living selling carbonated beverages, lollipops, and ice from her home with the help of her husband who manages a night club. She has been a member of the Communal Bank "Dulce Vida" for two years. Her first loan was for PEN 300 which she invested in the opening of her current business. With this PEN 2,300 loan, Anllela plans to purchase a motokar (motorized rickshaw) so that she can have another source of income in her home and be able to have another business. Anllela's goal is to own a place where she can offer a variety of refreshments, carbonated beverages, iced desserts, and other drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Rocio Vargas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a motokar

loans.name: Mighty God Group

texts.en:
Mighty God is a group of five borrowers led by Cecelia K., 35 years old. She is a high school graduate but couldn't afford to continue at the university due to lack of financial support. She is a single mother of four children aged 1-17 years old. They are in the third through ninth grade.

Cecelia's business is her little provisional shop where she sells bath soaps, detergent, washing soaps, candles, cheese, etc to the residents of Virginia, Northern Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for six years. The difficulty Cecelia faces is when customers buy her goods and don't pay on time for her to buy new goods.  However, because she talks to them in a good manner, they always want to patronize her business. She needs this loan in order to buy more goods like bathing soap, wheat, candles, etc.

Cecelia's goal is to grow from a shop to running a store. And she dreams of educating the children and building a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet P. is a 39-year old female entrepreneur from Kalubkob, Silang, Cavite.  Her husband is a community leader.  They have three children; the eldest is in college and the others are in high school.

Juliet owns a general store.  She went into business in 2006, the same year she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  Because she works hard, her business is continuously growing.  She uses her profits to support her children’s education.   

She is now on her 6th loan cycle with CCT and is requesting a new loan.  She will use the funds to purchase more items to sell at her general store.  Juliet dreams continuously improving her general store and having it evolve into a big store in the future.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase stock for general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Said Abrahim

texts.en:
This is S. AbR. son of S. A. R.. He lives in district 3 of Jalalabad city. He is 35 years old, married, and the father of four children: two sons and two daughters.

S. AbR. has a cotton-selling and cotton-gin (a machine that separates cotton fibers from the seeds) shop and through its income he supports his family.

S. AbR.’s income is low and he has a lot of business problems. When he was informed about the loan process that is supporting the people, he came to AFS and requested a loan of 50,000 Afghani. He will use the loan to buy cotton and to expand his business capacity.

S. AbR. hopes that, after taking the loan, it will increase his business income and he will solve his business problems, because he is a hardworking man.

S. AbR. would like to thank both Ariana Financial Services (AFS) and Kiva lenders who support people around the world through their effective loan process.

loans.use: To buy cotton

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne is 25 years old and is married with two school-age children. She has a shop called “Glory Suppliers” in which she sells snacks like groundnuts (peanuts) and provides a battery charging service. She's been in business for five years and employs three people.

Anne requested this loan of Kes 50,000 from Faulu to buy more groundnuts.

Anne describes herself as creative and hardworking and says that in Faulu, she has benefited by being able to interact freely with people from different communities. In the future, she hopes to expand her shop into a supermarket.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora Yolanda es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 3 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 28 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos. Estudió primaria completa y se dedica a la venta de jugos.
Yolanda nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar azúcar, plátanos, papaya, betarraga, alfalfa, etc.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia en Ilave.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Yolanda, 28, has been a member of the "Gran Poder" communal bank in Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department for the last 3 years. She lives with her life partner and their three children. She finished elementary school and she sells home-made fruit and vegetable juices. Yolanda tells us that with her first, 300 new sol, loan from the Manuela Ramos Movement she was able to increase her working capital. She will now request a 500 new sol loan with which to buy sugar, bananas, papayas, beets, alfalfa, etc. Her dream for the future is to own her own house in Ilave. What she likes most about her communal bank is the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, banana, papaya, beets, alfalfa.

loans.name: Dioba

texts.fr: Âgée de 29 ans, Dioba N. est une femme mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KA FALL depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle fait de l’embouche bovine et ovine et ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.
texts.en:
Dioba N. is a 29 year-old married mother of four. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois de KA FALL for three and a half years. She is involved in the fattening of cattle and sheep, and the profits that she generates from this enable her to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Enable her to finance her business autonomously

loans.name: Tin's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Tin H. is 32 years old. He is a widower and the leader of this group loan. The group consists of five members and is located in Prey Phnhi village, Takeo province. This loan will be used by the members to support different purposes. 

Mr. Tin H. is a silk weaver who can earn a small income to support himself, but now he wants to increase and expand his business. Thus, he is asking for 500,000 KHR to bU. more silk to continue and support his business.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana  es cliente de la Institución desde el año 2004 se dedica a la venta de golosinas, su kiosco se encuentra ubicado en los patios de la EMI (Escuela Militar de Ingenieria) el mismo esta en la zona de Alto Irpavi, su familia esta conformada por su esposo el mismo que es portero de dicha Institución, y ocupan una pequeña casita con sus dependencias que la Institución les proporciona, ellos tienen 3 hijos menores, dos de los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar y dependen de ellos; la señora tiene una casita propia que se encuentra en la zona de El Alto donde  viven sus dos hijos mayores ya independientes, el credito que saca de la institución le sirve de mucho ya que con ello trabaja para aumentar su capìtal en el kiosco ya que con el mismo cubre los gastos familiares. el monto que esta solicitando es el que hace rotar por toda la temporada de clases en la EMI.siendo esta actividad la única que tiene, es conveniente la tasa preferencial para doña Juanita. 

Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Juana has been a client of the Institution since 2004. She sells sweets, and her kiosk is located on the campus of the EMI (Military School of Engineering), which is in the Alto Irpavi area. Her family is comprised of her husband, a doorman for that institution, and their three minor children. Two of the children are school-age and dependent upon them. They live in a small house that the institution provides. She has her own small house in the El Alto region. Her two grown and independent children live there. The loan that she gets from the institutions will do a lot. She will use it to increase her capital in the kiosk because the kiosk covers the family expenses. The amount that she is requesting is what she needs for the entire season of classes at the EMI. As this activity is the only one she has, she gets a good interest rate. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence shown in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola is 55 years old and married with four children. She makes lovely Nigerian hair styles for her customers. She also sells salon materials like shampoo, hair extensions, etc. 
She is happy in her business because she is able to help support her household with the profits that she makes. Her husband sells equipment to help support their household, also.
Adeola hopes for a loan amount of 70,000 Nigerian Naira (NGN) to purchase more salon materials to sell. She hopes to own a world-class salon in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more salon materials.

loans.name: Alda

texts.en: Alda A. is from the village of Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Alda owns and operates an agriculture business. The main source of income for the business comes from planting banana trees and harvesting bananas for sale. Alda has been doing this for more than three years and earns approximately 9000 PHP per month for these activities. Alda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from GDMPC. Alda is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be Alda's fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business growing and selling bananas

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka J. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes and onions to sell.  Nyoka is 29 years old and married to a soldier. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
N. Moses has subsisted on a produce sales business for four years. At the young age of 24 years, he is a fledgling business trendsetter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other youth in his home area of Kisiita in Mubende district. Many youth in his home area preoccupy themselves in self-destructive activity like drinking. With his hard work, he has managed to take firm root and in a week he apparently makes 50,000 shillings.

With his monthly savings, Moses has managed to diversify his small business. This has, however, not come the easy way as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as the unpredictable weather patterns which, for the most part, mean he has fewer supplies from farmers.

Moses’ dream is to build his own produce stalls to store and keep his surplus goods. With this loan he hopes to implement the aforementioned.

loans.use: To construct extended stalls and a store for selling his produce and for storing his goods

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah C. is 48 years old, married, and the father of nine children ranging in age from 2 to 25 years old, 6 of whom are still attending school. Elijah has a mixed farm near Litein town in the South Rift Valley of Kenya. He has been dairy farming for six years, having previously just grown maize, and now sells milk directly to customers in town; in addition he cultivates tea and runs a cattle trade business. He says that the main challenges to his business are a lack of feed and suitable shelter for his cows.

Elijah has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, having previously completed a loan of Kshs. 45,000. He is now requesting a loan of Kshs. 50,000 to buy another dairy cow, declaring that the extra income from this loan will help him pay his children's schools fees and have a happy family. His focus is to improve his standard of living through additional income from farming.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chicas Superpoderosas Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal CHICAS SUPER PODEROSAS, en su Secuencia 4, está formado por 10 personas, 9 mujeres y 1 varón, la mayoría D. las socias pertenecen a la Zona D. Alto San Isidro, que están ubicados cerca D. la parada D. minibuses 211,  las socias se dedican a la venta D. ropa, costura y venta D. polleras, repostería y también hay una trabajadora  del hogar, etc. En la secuencia anterior todas cancelaron muy bien, además adelantaron por un día el último pago, no tuvieron problemas D. mora en ninguno D. sus pagos son socias que se conocen muy bien.

La Sra. Gabriela es la representante, actualmente toma el cargo D. la presidenta del banco se dedica a la venta D. ropa por la calle Tumusla, cuenta con esta actividad hace 1 año, el préstamo será destinado a incrementar su capital.  Tiene un hijo con el señor Jhonny, el cual es su concubino. En su banco comunal se ha destacado como una persona responsable y puntual en sus pagos, también fue anteriormente D. la mesa directiva, siendo una buena guía para su banco, con el dinero D. credito comprara mercaderia y asi poder incrementar su capital D. trabajo.

La Sra. Flora Socia que asume el cargo D. tesorera del banco, trabaja en una fotocopiadora cerca D. la universidad mayor D. San Andes hace 3 años, el préstamo esta destinado a la compra D. material D. escritorio papel en cantidad y tintas para la fotocopiadora que comparte con familiares. Casada con el señor Eusebio  tiene un hijo. Es una D. las representantes en su banco comunal, que ha sido elegida para el cargo por su  responsabilidad que ha demostrado dentro del banco como garante y como mesa directiva dentro D. la banca. 

El Sr. Fidel  es elegido como secretario, se dedica a la construcción D. viviendas, es albañil. El préstamo esta destinado para la compra D. herramientas para su trabajo, vive con su esposa Juana. Su meta es realizar contratos, como especie D. contratista ya que cuenta con gente que desea trabajar como albañiles y ayudantes.

Todas las socias son personas trabajadoras, estan agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The Banco Comunal Chicas Super Poderosas (Superpower Girls Community Bank) is presently in its 4th cycle, and it is composed of 10 people, 9 women and 1 man. The majority of the members live in the Alto San Isidro area, located close to the 211 minibus stop. The members sell a variety of things: clothes, dresses and skirts, cakes, and one is a maid. In the previous cycle all the members have been very punctual with their repayments, the last repayment was even maD. one day in advance with respect to the deadline, and none of them received a fine for belated repayments: these are indeed very well acknowledged entrepreneurs. Gabriela is their representative, she is now the president of the bank and sells clothes in Tumusla street. She has been running this business for 1 year, and the loan she is requesting will be used to increase her income. She has a child with her partner, Jhonny. In her Community Bank she has proven herself to be a responsible person, accurate with her payments; she was formerly employed in the directing board, where she proved to be a good guiD. for the bank. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy products to increase her income. Flora is the treasurer, she has been working in a photocopy shop close to the San Andes main university for 3 years. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy office items, many reams of paper and inks for the photocopier she shares with some relatives. She is married with Eusebio and has a child. She is one of the representatives of her Community Bank, and she has been elected to the post for the responsibility she has shown in the bank as a guarantor and as part of the banks’ directing board. Fidel has been elected secretary: he builds houses, he is construction worker. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy tools for his job . He lives with his wife Juana, and he aims to sign contracts and to become a contractor, as he can count on people willing to work as builders and helpers. All the members are hard-working people, thankful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence shown in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase their income.

loans.name: Unidas Para Seguir 1 Group

texts.en:
Celeste is the coordinator of her group, Unidas Para Seguir(United for Progress), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the lush, rugged Samana peninsuL., an area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their two children.

Celeste is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small cafeteria by purchasing bread, juice, sodas, papayas, cookies and a blender to supply her cafeteria. She will use the profits to invest in her own university education, as well as buying school supplies for her children. She would also like to invest in her home by remodeling it and in her business by finding a permanent location and moving it out of her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase bread, juice, sodas, papayas, cookies and a blender.

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
OIn the photo are members of the “Unity” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each from Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Memunatu T. who is pictured on the left. Memunatu is age 40; she was born in Makeni. She is married to a businessman and they have 5 children. Three of her children are attending primary school and 2 are in secondary school.

Memunatu sells firewood and fried cakes. She has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy piles of firewood, a bag of flour, gallons of frying oil, etc. in order to expand the size of her business.

loans.use: Buy piles of firewood, a bag of flour, gallons of frying oil, etc.

loans.name: Jehova Es Mi Pastor 4 Group

texts.en:
Milady is the coordinator of her group Jehova es mi Pastor 4 (God is my Pastor 4). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti, generally. Her group is located in Santiago, an area famous for tobacco and beef production and the second biggest city in Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with a child.

Milady is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business stand by buying vegetables and fruits. She will use the profits to expand the business and get her own house to live comfortably. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Vegetables, fruits and other items

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita L., from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City, is 46 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Cristita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Cristita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
N. Betty is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala east region of Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child who goes to school.  Betty has a business selling food in a small hotel. She has been doing this for 6 years.         

To help expand her business, Betty is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hotel materials like cups and oil. Betty plans to use the loan to expand her business and generate a profit to help her child.  In the future, Betty hopes to own a house.




Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Marta Teresa De Jesus

texts.es: María Teresa De Jesús Ramírez cuenta con su negocio de la venta de ropa usada desde hace 10 años donde manifiesta vender ropa de buena calidad y de diferentes tallas, lo cual requiere de un préstamo para comprar más mercancía; como ya se aproxima la temporada de frio quiere estar preparada. Su esposo trabaja como guardia de seguridad para apoyar con los gastos de la casa.
texts.en:
María Teresa De Jesús Ramírez has been selling used clothes for 10 years. She sells high-quality clothes of many different sizes. She needs a loan to buy more merchandise so that she will be ready for the cold season. Her husband works as a security guard.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchadise

loans.name: Leh We Believe Weself Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Aminata T.. Aminata who is 40 was born in Makeni city. She is married to a businessman and they have three children. One of the children is in primary school and two are secondary school.  

For 15 years now, Aminata has been selling gara lappers (locally dyed cloths, sometimes with fabricated designs). With her share of this loan, Aminata is going to expand her business by buying gara lapper making materials including inks, caustic soda, powder, white cotton cloths, etc in order to produce more gara cloths to sell.

loans.use: Buy gara lapper making materials

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en: Ginalyn M. is a 27-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating an abaca (a plant fiber) weaving business. She lives in Tontonon, Masaba, Danao City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her abaca weaving business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ginalyn is now borrowing PHP 16,000 so that she can purchase raw materials for her business. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ginalyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and assure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Balbina

texts.en:
Balbina N. is from the village of San Isidro, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 61 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $163 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Balbina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Balbina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma C. is from the village of Minlagas, Gingoog City. She is 48 years old. Erma is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Erma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling food and daily use products like sardines, instant noodles, sanitary napkins, baby diapers and variety of soft drinks in the local community. Erma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Erma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Erma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gustavo Adolfo

texts.es:
GUSTAVO ADOLFO S. B., Trabaja como Contador A en la Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería. es padre de familia de un niño y este se encuentra en el colegio, el prestamo solicitado es para la compra de materiales de construcción va invertirlo en cambiar el techo de su casa.
ha trabajado cuatro prestamo con ceprodel y estos han sido para el mejoramiento de su vivienda.
texts.en: Gustavo Adolfo S. B. works as an accountant at the Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería (National University of Engineering).  He is father to one child who is in school.  The loan which he is requesting will be used to buy building materials and to replace the roof of his house.  He has had four loans with CEPRODEL and they have all been used to improve his house.

loans.use: To purchase building materials and replace the roof of his house

loans.name: Celia Jenny

texts.es:
Celia Jenny G. M.  tiene 41 años. Es viuda,  vive con los padres y con un hijo,  vive  en el cantón de Ventanas en la Provincia de Los Ríos. Tiene 1 hijo. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. El Recreo este grupo se dedica exclusivamente a labores agrícolas especialmente a la siembra de cultivo de ciclo corto como es el maíz, arroz, soya y fréjol. Todos los socios son del mismo sector recinto San Vicente Las lomas Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos a esta ventanillas pertenecen 12 socios.

Celia se dedica a la agricultura especialmente a la siembra de maíz desde hace 3 años. Compra sus productos en Ventanas y los vende en la feria de Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño seguir trabajando por un futuro mejor.
Le gusta leer.
texts.en:
Celia Jenny G. M. is 41 years old, she is widowed and lives with her parents and son, she lives in the area of Ventanas in the province of Los Ríos, and she has 1 son.

The members of the V.R.C. El Recreo group mainly work in the agricultural field, especially growing short-cycle crops like corn, rice, soy and beans, the communal bank has 12 members. All the members are from the same area of San Vicente in Las Lomas, Cantón Ventanas, Los Ríos Province.

Celia is a farmer and she specializes in growing corn, she has done so for 3 years. She buys her products in Ventanas and sells them in a market in the same city.

Celia needs the loan to buy farming supplies and fertilizers for her corn crops. The loan will help her meet her financial needs. Some problems that she faces are plagues and disease and climate change. Her dream is to keep working for a better future.

Celia enjoys reading.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies and fertilizers.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher is a twenty-eight-year-old enterprising married man with three children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. For fifteen years he has been farming and has also been in the motorcycle transport business amidst challenges with seasonal changes and unpredictable customers. His dream is to own  a motorcycle as he still has to remit some of his daily income to the current owner of the motorcycle he uses. Christopher intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle for his own transport business.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 34 years old and married. She is blessed with two children, aged 11and 7.  For a living, she does gardening and landscaping. She has been running the business for three years and she has employed 28 people. She was previously selling clinic equipment for a living.  

She hopes to stabilize her business so that she gets more customers.  With the loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she will buy more flowers for planting in her nursery.

loans.use: To buy flowers to plant in a nursery

loans.name: Mathias

texts.en: Mathias Bahati N. is thirty eight years old and married with two children aged thirteen and nine. His business is located at Pirates beach in Mombasa, the coastal region of Kenya well known for its many many tourist attractions — not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. He has been selling stone carvings and sculptures for the last five years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy wood and stones to make more carvings to meet the high demand, especially during the Christmas season. He hopes to give a good life to his family and describes himself as customer friendly.

loans.use: Wood and stone

loans.name: Arise Club-Mpigi Group

texts.en: 30 year old K. Abdul has been in the motorcycle transportation business for the past 8 years in Kayabwe-Mpigi. Abdul also does poultry farming. He says he began his motorcycle business soon after the completion of school. Before, he took root in this business, he was more inclined to buying and selling agro produce. Weekly this business generates him shillings 70,000 and he says with this loan, he is going to buy more chicken mash for his poultry. Abdul belongs to Arise club-Mpigi.

loans.use: The purchase of more chicken mash for his poultry

loans.name: Willian Enrique

texts.es: William P.  tiene 25 años y es el propietario del negocio   “Tienda panadería Calibres y un profesional de la Comunicación Social  , que  agregó su experiencia  emprendedora desde cuando estudiaba en la universidad  y en sus tiempos libres se dedicaba a la fabricación de bolsos de lona aprovechando el mercado doméstico de sus compañeros de estudio;  posteriormente también construyó otra experiencia emprendedora, cuando se asoció con una amiga y crearon una microempresa de congelados empacados al vacio como deditos, empanaditas y demás picadas. Hace dos años su capacidad innovadora lo llevó a  alquilar  el garaje de un apartamento y a comprar  equipos con los cuáles puso en funcionamiento una panadería y como tuvo mucha acogida entre su clientela, gradualmente ha ido adicionándole otros productos  solicitados por sus clientes como  víveres :  arroz, aceite, azúcar y granos, hasta llegar a que hoy el 50% de su venta corresponda a víveres y el otro 50% a productos de panadería; simultáneamente William aprovecha su espacio comercial para ofrecer el servicio de llamadas y recargas a celulares, con los cuales obtiene un ingreso adicional. En su negocio ocupa los servicios de un panadero que trabaja de lunes sábado y maneja un promedio de ventas diarias de $350.000 COP y un  margen de utilidad promedio de 35%  . El financiamiento solicitado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo es el primero con el cual comprará  ranchos víveres, e insumos de panadería,  para aumentar el surtido de su tienda y comprar materias primas e insumos en mayor cantidad con tal de obtener descuentos. Su meta es agregar a su negocio aprovechando el nicho de mercado en el que está posicionado, la elaboración y ventas de comidas rápidas y jugos naturales, negocio que funcionaria en la terraza de la tienda que es bien amplia.
texts.en:
William P., 25, owns his own business, "The Calibres Bakery," and is a communications professional.  He has broadened his business experience since his university studies, where in his free time he earned his living making canvas bags, taking advantage of the local market provided by his fellow students.
